Triad of Deans to Direct Homewood Campus
The administrative structure
of the Homewood campus will
be reorganized for next year,
according to Dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences
George Fisher and Dean of the
G.W.C. Whiting School of
David
V.

VandeLinde.

academic and non-academic affairs will be "streamlined,"

creative energies of a full

Another Dean
President Steven Muller and the
Homewood Deans have announced their intention to introduce a new position to the
existing administrative structure at Johns
Hopkins. A new dean, they say, will help to
"streamline" affairs into the separate areas
of academics and non-academics. Supposedly, such changes in the system will allow
Homewood to run more smoothly and
efficiently.
A potentially negative response may result
from such a move. Undergraduates especially are likely to assume that this is merely
another addition to the already confusing
tangle of bureaucracy and red tape that exists here. Another administrator may simply mean one more person to contribute to
. the sometimes perplexing policies issued
from the hallowed halls of Garland and
Merryman.
However, it might be wise to put aside our
cynicism for a moment. The new dean, who
will hold a rank equivalent to that of Arts
and Sciences Dean Fisher and Engineering
Dean Vandelinde, will have his primary
responsibilities centered about non-academic
affairs. This will include such diverse concerns as student amenities, auxiliary enter-

prises, the Office of the Registrar and
housing.
Obviously, students have a vested interest
in these areas and would benefit from any
improvement in their organizational structure. The current situation demands that all
questions concerning non-academic affairs
be channeled through several offices, including those of Fisher and Vandelinde, who
must then consult with one another before
reaching a decision. The process is timeconsuming and, at times, irritating to
witness.
A single dean, however, whose principal

To the Editor:
In last week's News-Letter,
staff writer Ron Zucker reviewed Jean-Francois Revel's excellent book, How Democracies
Perish. Having followed
Revel's work for some time, I
was surprised to see that the
review ran under the headings

"Revel's Conservatism." Mr.
Zucker, in spite of having supposedly read Revel's work,
seems to be completely unaware
that Jean-Francois revel is, and
has long been, a well-known
French socialist.
In his 1970 work Without
Marx or Jesus, Revel writes
that" .the American Left is
probably the world's only hope
for a revolution that will save
it from destruction." He also
sets forth his"... program for
the revolution that mankind
needs: the abolition of war and
of imperialist relations by
abolishing both states and the
notion of national sovereignty;
. ..world-wide economic and
educational equality; birth control on a planetary scale...
and states that this program "is
absolutely necessary if mankind
is to survive."
In his 1977 work The
Totalitarian Temptation, Revel
confirms his strong support for
democratic socialism while opposing all totalitarian systems
of government. The message

and tone of How Democracies
Perish is the same. Yet Mr.
Zucker was able to read the entire book (one hopes), all the
while thinking that Revel was a
conservative!

him to make the most absurd
statements: "Shockingly, for I
am a life-long liberal, I happen
to agree with Mr. Revel's conclusions..." Shockingly? "To
his credit, Mr. Revel [does not
condemn] the International
Socialist Organzation, or any
other of the legitimate Socialist
groups." Why would it even
occur to Zucker that Revel,

to condemn socialism?

unwittingly accepted the
McCarthyist notion that only
conservatives can beanticommunist; therefore, Mr.

conservative. Hence the necessity to make absurd disavowals

In the future, book reviewers
should be more careful about
printing gross factual errors.

are very bright points of light,
the total power of which can be
100 or 1000 times greater than
the power from all the stars in
the galaxy. These galaxies are
not particularly larger or
smaller than non-active ones
such as ours, nor are these
galaxies tremendously different
from ordinary galaxies in their
other properties, so scientists
do not really know what causes
the bright center.
By studying the spectra of the
light received from these galaxies, it is known that whatever is

President Steven Muller and the
Homewood Deans have announced their intention to introduce a new position to the
existing administrative structure at Johns
Hopkins. A new dean, they say, will help to
"streamline" affairs into the separate areas
of academics and non-academics. Supposedly, such changes in the system will allow
Homewood to run more smoothly and
efficiently.
A potentially negative response may result
from such a move. Undergraduates especially are likely to assume that this is merely
another addition to the already confusing
tangle of bureaucracy and red tape that exists here. Another administrator may simply mean one more person to contribute to
. the sometimes perplexing policies issued
from the hallowed halls of Garland and
Merryman.
However, it might be wise to put aside our
cynicism for a moment. The new dean, who
will hold a rank equivalent to that of Arts
and Sciences Dean Fisher and Engineering
Dean Vandelinde, will have his primary
responsibilities centered about non-academic
affairs. This will include such diverse concerns as student amenities, auxiliary enter-

prises, the Office of the Registrar and
housing.
Obviously, students have a vested interest
in these areas and would benefit from any
improvement in their organizational structure. The current situation demands that all
questions concerning non-academic affairs
be channeled through several offices, including those of Fisher and Vandelinde, who
must then consult with one another before
reaching a decision. The process is timeconsuming and, at times, irritating to
witness.
A single dean, however, whose principal
focus is on auxiliary services would offer a
significant advantage. Non-academic activities would be addressed at the same level
as that of academic concerns. In addition,
we would lose nothing to this development.
Academics and non-academics alike would
receive added attention. The administrative
hierarchy, a necessary evil, could be
improved.
Students should support these changes.
Our opinions and suggestions about the position should be solicited and given. There is
a great deal to be gained from this decision.

Aquarium.
Humbly,
Jim Keim

To the Editor:
In last week's News-Letter,
staff writer Ron Zucker reviewed Jean-Francois Revel's excellent book, How Democracies
Perish. Having followed
Revel's work for some time, I
was surprised to see that the
review ran under the headings
"Democracy's Shortfalls: A
Conservative's View" and
"Revel's Conservatism." Mr.
Zucker, in spite of having supposedly read Revel's work,
seems to be completely unaware
that Jean-Francois revel is, and
has long been, a well-known
French socialist.
In his 1970 work Without
Marx or Jesus, Revel writes
that" .the American Left is
probably the world's only hope
for a revolution that will save
it from destruction." He also
sets forth his"... program for
the revolution that mankind
needs: the abolition of war and
of imperialist relations by
abolishing both states and the
notion of national sovereignty;
. ..world-wide economic and
educational equality; birth control on a planetary scale...
and states that this program "is
absolutely necessary if mankind
is to survive."
In his 1977 work The
Totalitarian Temptation, Revel
confirms his strong support for
democratic socialism while opposing all totalitarian systems
of government. The message

and tone of How Democracies
Perish is the same. Yet Mr.
Zucker was able to read the entire book (one hopes), all the
while thinking that Revel was a
conservative!
Zucker's misconception leads
him to make the most absurd
statements: "Shockingly, for I
am a life-long liberal, I happen
to agree with Mr. Revel's conclusions..." Shockingly? "To
his credit, Mr. Revel [does not
condemn] the International
Socialist Organzation, or any
other of the legitimate Socialist
groups." Why would it even
occur to Zucker that Revel,
himself a socialist, would wish
to condemn socialism?
Apparently, Mr. Zucker has
unwittingly accepted the
McCarthyist notion that only
conservatives can beanticommunist; therefore, Mr.
Zucker blunders, he must be a
conservative. Hence the necessity to make absurd disavowals
when discussing Revel's ideas.
In the future, book reviewers
should be more careful about
printing gross factual errors.
Sincerely,
Stephen Pimentel

This weekend, the Hopkins
